All radio stations want to give their
listeners good and varied programmes.
When it concerns music, a symphony, a
popular concert or a jazz programme all
strive to obtain the best possible orchestras
and the best possible quality.
The cost for such programmes is high, as
the remuneration paid to the required num¬
ber of musicians is heavy. Therefore, the
quality often suffers, since one avoids
engaging more musicians than are absolutely
necessary. Frequently, just those extra in¬
struments which provide the full richness
of tone in the music are missing.
Exchange of progfammes
Radio stations have been used to exchanging
programmes between themselves. However,
this only results in an equation of 1: 1.
This has reduced the cost for just these
programmes and thus enabled the use of
larger orchestras.
Programme costs can be reduced and
the quality improved!
Swedish Radio and TV Programme Service
gives all radio stations the opportunity to
provide programmes of music more cheaply,
with larger orchestras and of improved
quality, and thus the possibility of increased
musical programmes of the highest quality.
Gramophone recordings can be reduced and
replaced by live programmes.
Our programme service supplies at low
cost programmes of all kinds of music,
recorded by the best orchestras. These
programmes can be bought for l/lO to 1/20
of what a broadcasting station would have
to pay to produce such a programme itself.

We reserve to ourselves the right, however,
of final decision. A team of good judges of
music and skilled technicians listen to the
incoming programmes before they are accep¬
ted. Every programme must bear details of
the name and size of the orchestra, the
name of the conductor and soloist, if any,
the date and place of recording together
with the contents of the programme, length
of playing time and standard NARTB or
CCIR. As soon as a programme is approved,
it is added to our list, which is sent out
at regular intervals to all radio stations.

In this way every radio station has the
opportunity to obtain a wider choice and
greater variety of musical programmes and
every country’s typical and special music
can be sent from one broadcasting station
to another — and at l/lO to 1/20 of the
normal production cost.
This exchange system also improves the
position of the musicians concerned, since
larger orchestras than formerly can be
used and several programmes can be
produced at a lower total cost for the
broadcasting station.
Our activities are inter-continental and the
organisation is under expansion with offices
in several places all over the world.
. Recording of Scandinavian music.
At present there is a number of recordings
of typical Scandinavian music by Scandina¬
vian composers. There is a choice of sympho¬
nic as well as popular light music. Famous
orchestras and perfect technical equipment
have been used.
Our technical equipment is of the highest
quality and of the most modern type. There
is a, complete Ampex recording outfit, a
large and a small music studio. Copies are
made on an Ampex copying machine and
the qualities listed on next side can be
guaranteed for every programme we supply:
Both NARTB and CCIR standards can be
obtained. A programme coming in to us
in one of these standards can be transferred
to the other without any loss of quality.
Programme copying is carried
out by us.
It you need to obtain a copy of a tape
recording for some purpose, we undertake
such work at low cost, Sw. Kr. 2: 50 per
1200 ft. Such copies can be obtained at the
same speed and standard as the original, or
at any other speed from 60 to 3%" per
second with retained or transferred stan¬
dard. Tapes for copies can be supplied
either by you or by us. In the former case
we can, through a special agreement, obtain
these tapes free of customs duty to and
from Sweden, and in the latter case the tape
is supplied at prices in accordance with the
attached list.
We shall be pleased to supply any further
information and will send a sample tape on
request. These contain partly a recorded
frequency curve, and partly extracts from
different recordings, from which the quality
can be judged. 'These trial recordings are
made from copies already issued, so that
they completely correspond to the quality
which is to be found in all programmes
issued by us.
Contact us for further information and for
requisition of lists of programmes and
prices.
